meeting_annotations.speaker: Jennifer Wilcox
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is prompting the group for final comments before the breakout room closes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rebecca Gieseking
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just had a question because it's not something that I'm really familiar with. These like pumping CO2 into the ground type things, how permanent is that or does it tend to leak back out?
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker prefaces her question by stating her lack of familiarity with the topic, inviting an expert explanation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jennifer Wilcox
meeting_annotations.transcript: So so if it's in a depleted oil and gas reservoir, the the CO2 trapping mechanism is really the same as what's been trapping the oil and gas for millions of years. And so the likelihood of it leaking back out is pretty negligible. We've been doing projects like that in the Permian Basin in Texas since 1972 and there's been zero leakage and zero accidents of CO2, so it's it's pretty good. But at the same time, those are the projects that are such controversial topics because they also, as Feng said, like that's not the answer. You're releasing more CO2 in the form of burning crude oil in the end. And so if there were opportunity but it doesn't mean you can't use depleted oil and gas wells to to store CO2, it's just that can we do that and not take more oil out of the ground? Because those formations are really appropriate for carbon storage. The saline aquifers are another option, but the the difference is is we have to characterize them better, we have to know more about them because they don't necessarily have say a low permeability cap rock that will keep the CO2 physically trapped initially. So they just require a lot more characterization. Yeah. And and people, I think a big part of this is just public acceptance and whether or not every culture or community is comfortable with the idea of putting carbon dioxide, you know, underground in their backyard. And I think that that's another issue. It looks like we're going to be cut off in 30 seconds. So we'll see you guys back in the in the main room.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker provides a detailed, expert answer, covering both the technical and social aspects of the question, and then manages the transition back to the main meeting room.
